text: Content Standard 1.0: The Economic Way of Thinking: Students will use fundamental economic concepts, including scarcity, choice, cost, incentives, and costs versus benefits to describe and analyze problems and opportunities, both individual and social.

children.text: Scarcity, Choice, and Cost
Give examples of what is given up when choices are made.
Categorize wants as goods, services, or leisure activities.
Describe how scarcity requires a person to make a choice and identify a cost associated with the decision.
Use the concept of opportunity cost to evaluate the tradeoffs when choices occur.
Explain why choices and their costs may differ across individuals and societies.
Incentives and Preferences
Give examples of incentives and determine whether they are positive or negative.
Demonstrate an understanding that people may respond to the same incentive in different ways because they may have different preferences.
Recognize that self-interest is a motivational factor when people respond to incentives.
Recognize that people act out of self-interest and predict how a change in the economic environment will affect the choices made by consumers, producers, and savers.
Cost versus Benefits
Give examples of an all-or-nothing choice such as choosing to have music on or off.
Identify the benefits and the costs of an all-or-nothing choice such as choosing to have music on or off.
Demonstrate an understanding that choosing a little more or a little less generates either a benefit or a cost.
Identify the additional benefits and the additional costs that result from choosing a little more or a little less.
Examine decisions made by individuals, businesses, and government by comparing the marginal benefits and marginal costs.
Personal Economics
Identify the benefits and costs of spending now versus saving for later.
Evaluate career paths by comparing costs and benefits.
Evaluate career paths by comparing costs and benefits.
Give examples of and evaluate the effectiveness of incentive systems used by parents, teachers, and employers.

text: Content Standard 2.0: Measuring U.S. Economic Performance: Students will demonstrate a knowledge of past and present U.S. economic performance, identify the economic indicators used to measure that performance, and use this knowledge to make individual decisions and discuss social issues.

children.text: Measuring Economic Growth
Identify and use per capita measures in the classroom (such as the number of pencils per student).
Identify and compare per capita measures for the U.S. for different time periods.
Explain gross domestic product (GDP) and how it is used to describe a country's economic output.
Given data on population and GDP for several countries, determine their per capita GDP, and compare with the United States.
Explain the difference between nominal GDP and real GDP.
Using real GDP per capita as a measure of the standard of living, describe how living standards have changed over time.
Using the change in real GDP, examine the U.S. economy over time, identi-fying recessions and high and low rates of growth.
Measuring Inflation
Define inflation and deflation and explain how they affect individuals.
Use the consumer price index (CPI) to compare the buying power of the U.S. dollar in one year with its buying power in another year.
Using a price index to measure inflation, identify when the U.S. economy has experienced high and low rates of inflation and discuss their effects
Use various price indexes to determine how the prices of different types of goods and services have changed.
Measuring Unemployment
Discuss why people seek work.
Define employment and unemployment.
Identify the unemployment rate as the percentage of people in the labor force who are not working, but who are actively pursuing work.
Distinguish between a high rate and a low rate of unemployment for the U.S. economy over time.
Explain and give examples of the costs of unemployment to the economy as a whole (such as lost income, lost tax revenue, and additional welfare burdens).
Compare the unemployment rates for groups of people who differ by age, gender, ethnic origin, occupation, and educational attainment.
Measuring Interest
Identify and give examples of interest rates for borrowing and saving.
Explain why riskier loans command higher interest rates than safer loans.
Distinguish between high and low interest rates for the U.S. economy over time.
Explain why a real interest rate accurately measures the benefit of saving or the cost of borrowing.
Demonstrate knowledge of when interest rate levels have experienced relative highs and relative lows throughout U.S. history and discuss their effects.
Personal Economics
Identify career fields that are experiencing growth and career fields that are experiencing decline.
Characterize different career paths according to the rates of job growth and employment opportunities.
Explain ways a high interest rate could be detrimental or beneficial.
Evaluate saving and borrowing options in terms of interest and compare long- and short-term costs and benefits.

text: Content Standard 3.0: Functioning of Markets: Students will demonstrate an understanding of how markets work, including an understanding of why markets form, how supply and demand interact to determine market prices and interest rates, and how changes in prices act as signals to coordinate trade.

children.text: Trade Is Beneficial
Demonstrate an understanding of trade.
Differentiate between barter and monetary trade.
Explain why trade must be mutually beneficial.
Give examples of markets in which people benefit from trade.
Demonstrate an understanding that all voluntary trade, by definition, benefits both parties.
Markets Determine Prices
Give examples of prices people have paid when buying goods and services.
Give examples of prices received by a business for selling goods and services.
Demonstrate an understanding of supply and demand in a market.
Explain how supply and demand function to determine market prices.
Use the concepts of supply and demand to analyze and predict the price changes occurring in markets for goods and services.
Prices as Signals
Give reasons why consum-ers choose to buy more of a good or service (including when its price is low) and when they choose to buy less (including when its price is high).
Give reasons why producers choose to sell more of a good or service (including when a price is high) and when they choose to sell less (including when its price is low
Contrast the effects of price changes on the behavior of buyers and sellers.
Explain why buyers demand less yet sellers supply more when prices go up.
Explain why buyers demand more yet sellers supply less when prices go down.
Use the concept of price elasticity to analyze how buyers and sellers might adjust their purchase and sales decisions in response to price changes.
Discuss the effects of price controls (price ceilings and price floors) (such as minimum wage, rent control).
Determining Interest Rates
Use supply and demand to explain how interest rates are determined.
Personal Economics
Identify instances in which people might pay interest or receive interest.
Explain the factors that should be considered when making individual purchasing decisions, given changes in prices.
Analyze and predict instances in which people pay high and low interest rates (such as car loans and credit cards).
Analyze family spending decisions, drawing conclusions about the desirability of making substitutions, given the relative prices of various substitutes.

text: Content Standard 4.0: Private U.S. Economic Institutions: Students will describe the roles played by various U.S. economic institutions, including financial institutions, labor unions, for-profit business organizations, and not-for-profit organizations.

children.text: Financial Institutions
Identify reasons people use banks.
Demonstrate an understanding of key banking terms, including saving, interest, and borrowing.
Identify financial institutions.
Explain the purposes and functions of financial institutions (such as to channel funds from savers to borrowers).
Analyze the roles of financial institutions in creating credit.
Labor Unions
Provide examples of labor unions.
Explain the purposes and functions of labor unions (such as collective bargaining).
Discuss how labor unions affect employees and employers.
For-profit Business Organizations
Identify a for-profit organization in the community and a service it provides.
Explain the purposes for establishing for-profit organizations.
Explain the advantages and disadvantages of each of the three primary forms of business organizations: sole proprietorship, partnership, and corporation
Identify current or historical mergers, buyouts, and acquisitions.
Not-for-profit Organizations
Identify a not-for-profit organization in the community and a service it provides.
Explain the purposes for establishing not-for-profit organizations.
Explain why not-for-profit organizations are tax exempt.
Explain how the services of not-for-profit organizations impact other economic institutions.
Personal Economics
Identify reasons for saving money.
Identify the rewards and risks of saving money in financial institutions.
Compare the rewards and risks of saving and borrowing money with several types of financial institutions.
Investigate careers associated with financial institutions, labor unions, for-profit business organizations, and not-for-profit organizations.
Compare and contrast the services offered by financial institutions, evaluating their usefulness to borrowers and lenders.
Compare and contrast careers associated with financial institutions, labor unions, for-profit business organizations, and not-for-profit organizations.

text: Content Standard 5.0: Money: Students demonstrate an understanding of various forms of money; how money makes it easier to trade, borrow, save, invest, and compare the value of goods and services; and how the Federal Reserve System and its policies affect the U.S. money supply.

children.text: Functions of Money
Explain what money is and how it is used.
Identify forms of money.
Explain why it is easier for people to save and trade using money rather than using other commodities.
Illustrate how prices stated in money terms help people compare the value of products.
Explain the three functions of money: medium of exchange, store of value, unit of account.
The Federal Reserve and the Banking System
Explain why the money supply increases when banks make loans.
Explain how the Federal Reserve influences bank loan activity using the reserve requirement, discount rate, and open market operations.
History of Money
Identify forms of money used in the United States prior to the twentieth century.
Describe the transition from the use of commodities as money to the use of modern forms of money.
Describe the nation's current money supply measures, including M1 and M2.
Personal Economics
Demonstrate an understanding that each family has a limited amount of money regardless of how it is accessed (through cash, check writing, or ATM).
Give examples of purchases made using credit.
Identify pros and cons of paying with cash versus using credit.
Explain what a credit rating is and how it affects access to money.

text: Content Standard 6.0: The U.S. Economy as a Whole: Students will demonstrate an understanding of the U.S. economic system as a whole in terms of how it allocates resources; determines the nation's production, income, unemployment, and price levels; and leads to variations in individual income levels.

children.text: Resource Allocation
Explain what a consumer does.
Explain what a producer does.
Demonstrate an understanding that an individual can be both a consumer and a producer.
Identify the resources needed for production in households, schools, and community groups.
Explain ways in which households, schools, or community groups allocate resources.
Explain how consumer and producer reactions to price changes affect resource allocation.
Compare the benefits and costs of allocating resources through markets or government.
Discuss how an economy determines what goods and services will be produced, how they will be produced, and who will receive them.
The Nation's Production Level
Recognize the three types of productive resources: natural (such as minerals), human (such as educated workers), and capital (such as machinery).
Explain how the current utilization of a productive resource affects the availability of that resource in the future.
Analyze the potential production of goods and services for a nation as determined by its resources and technology.
The Nation's Income Level
Demonstrate an understanding of and give examples of income.
Illustrate how one person's spending becomes another person's income.
Explain the circular flow of economic activity.
Explain how the multiplier can affect the nation's income.
The Nation's Unemployment Rate
Identify factors within an individual's control that can affect the likelihood of being employed.
Identify factors that can affect an individual's likelihood of being unemployed.
Make connections between the nation's unemployment rate and changes in seasons, changes in an industry, and changes in demographics.
Differences in Individual Incomes
Give examples of ways people earn money by working.
Demonstrate an understanding that different jobs require different skills and people receive different levels of income.
Describe how income reflects choices people make about education, training, skill development, lifestyle, and careers.
Explain that the wage individual's earn is affected by their productivity and by the market value of the goods or services they produce.
Explain how and why changes in product demand can affect the price of the product, which, in turn, can affect the wages paid to a worker.
Personal Economics
Identify a career path of interest and explain how the associated earnings are affected by the market.
Assess the attractiveness of career paths of interest and how they might be affected by changes in the national economy.

text: Content Standard 7.0: An Evolving Economy: Students will demonstrate an understanding of how investment, entrepreneurship, competition, and specialization lead to changes in an economy's structure and performance.

children.text: Investment
Explain how tools and machinery may help a person work faster or better, or make a person's work easier.
Explain how skill training and education can enhance the ability to produce goods and services.
Provide an example of how purchasing a tool or acquiring education can be an investment.
Explain how investment improves standards of living by increasing productivity.
Describe the past, present, and future role of investment in enhancing economic growth and raising living standards.
Identify the benefits and the costs of investing in new physical capital and new human capital.
Examine government's impact on investment through taxes, fees, government regulation, enterprise zones, and subsidies.
Entrepreneurship
Give examples of inventions.
List examples of entrepreneurs.
Describe the characteristics of an entrepreneur.
Describe the advantages and disadvantages of being an entrepreneur.
Discuss how entrepreneurs affect the economy by solving problems, taking risks, and taking advantage of opportunities to earn profits.
Competition
Describe what it means to compete.
Give examples of ways sellers compete.
Illustrate how competition among sellers decreases prices, while competition among buyers increases prices.
Explain how individual self-interest, channeled through the marketplace, can increase the overall standard of living.
Specialization
Explain why specialization increases productivity and interdependence.
Give examples of how specialization is facilitated by trade.
Discuss the pros and cons of specialization and interdependence.
Personal Economics
Describe the steps an entrepreneur would take to start a business.
Give examples of ways investment can improve students' performance in school, sports, etc.
Explain why top performers in any field are specialists.

text: Content Standard 8.0: The Role of Government in a Market Economy: Students will explain the role of government in a market economy.

children.text: Public Goods
Give examples of the kinds of goods and services that government provides.
Explain why government provides public goods rather than allowing the market to provide them.
Externalities
Give examples of activities that benefit participants, yet harm nonparticipants.
Explain why government intervenes in markets in response to externalities.
Redistributing Income
Identify methods by which government redistributes income.
Discuss whether redistributing income is an appropriate role of government.
Property Rights
Give examples of ways government protects property.
Demonstrate an under-standing that government must define, establish, and enforce property rights in order for markets to function.
Political Decisions
Explain why it is possible that a government decision may impose costs on many, but only benefit a few.
Fiscal Policy
Explain how fiscal policy affects production, employment, and price levels.
Personal Economics
Give examples of items for which a sales tax is charged and items for which a sales tax is not charged.
Describe how paying sales, property, and income taxes affect the amount of money an individual has available for spending.
Give examples of mandates that increase prices of goods and services in Nevada.

text: Content Standard 9.0: The International Economy: Students explore the characteristics of non-U.S. economic systems in order to demonstrate an understanding of how they are connected, through trade, to peoples and cultures throughout the world.

children.text: International Trade
Give examples of goods the U.S. imports and exports.
Explain why the U.S. imports and exports goods.
Explain how governments use tariffs or quotas to restrict trade.
Analyze the pros and cons of foreign trade, comparing free trade with restricted trade.
Interdependence
Identify the countries of origin of commonly used products.

Describe how the exchange of goods and services around the world creates interdependence among people in different places (such as the production of a candy bar requires ingredients from different countries around the world).
Describe how economic interdependence among countries affects standards of living in those countries.
Describe how foreign economic events can impact the U.S. economy.
Characteristics of Non-U.S. Economic Systems
Describe some characteris-tics of non-U.S. economies that affect international trade.
Exchange Rates
Identify the currencies of other countries.
Give the value of the U.S. dollar in terms of the currencies of other countries.
Compute prices of U.S. products in terms of other countries' currencies.
Determine how a change in exchange rates affects the ability of residents of one country to consume products from other countries.
Personal Economics
Identify goods that would not be readily available in U.S. stores if there were no international trade.
Draw conclusions about how the prices of goods you purchase would change if imports were restricted.
Discuss how potential career paths could be affected by changes in foreign demand for U.S. products.
